8801008:
EMERGENCY BRONCHOSCOPY â€“ HEMOPTYSIS
Patient: [REDACTED] | 62M | MRN [REDACTED]
Date: [REDACTED] 01:10 AM
Attending: Rachel O'Neal, MD

INDICATION:
Acute moderate-to-massive hemoptysis in patient with known cavitary RUL lesion

ANESTHESIA:
Intubated in ICU by critical care team (8.0 ETT). Bronchoscopy performed under deep sedation on ventilator.

DESCRIPTION:
Flexible bronchoscope advanced through the ETT. Large amounts of fresh blood were suctioned from trachea and
right mainstem bronchus.

RIGHT LUNG:
RUL found to be the bleeding source with active oozing from posterior segment. No foreign body or tumor id[REDACTED].

HEMOSTATIC MEASURES:
- Iced saline lavage 50 mL aliquots x4 (200 mL total) to RUL
- Topical epinephrine 1:10,000, 10 mL instilled to RUL
- Tranexamic acid 500 mg in 50 mL NS instilled via bronchoscope
- No radial EBUS, navigation, or biopsies were performed

Following these measures, bleeding slowed from brisk to scant oozing. Airway was packed with small amounts of
suctioned clot but remained patent. No balloon tamponade was required.

LEFT LUNG:
Normal, no blood.

No transbronchial biopsies, brushings, or BAL were performed because priority was hemorrhage control.

COMPLICATIONS:
None beyond initial hemorrhage.

DISPOSITION:
Remain intubated in ICU, plan for IR bronchial artery embolization later this morning.

CPT (requested): 31634, 31622
